The Writing on the Wall
This is actually a transcription
of a dialogue I found on the wall
of a restroom near the poli-sci
office, in Gilman Hall. This is the
honest, no shit, text. (Sorry
about the pun.)
(1) Bathrooms are society's
great levelers—for here all men
are equal.
(2) Stop writing on the walls,
you ill-bred peasant!
(3) Dear ignorant critic, This is
an access door, not a wall. Learn
this and you can go on to colors.
.(4) Please ignore the above

letters to the editor
To the.Editor
We are writing with respect to
the front page article headlined
"Imminent Purchase of
Baltimorean Angers Residents"
Which appeared in your Friday,
October 10 issue. The article
details the claims of the Charles
Village Civic Association in
regard to the impending purchase
of the apartment building at
2905 N. Charles St. by the
University.

The Association alleges that
they had not been consulted
about the acquisition. This
committee had intended to send
a representative to the October 8
meeting of the group; however,
when Dean Hall contacted the
CVCA about the matter, he was
requested not to have one of our
committee members present at
the meeting.
Ironically, the Association
members quoted accuse Johns

THERE! A NEW LAND
TO CONQUER!

Hopkins of lack of cooperation,
when it was clear that
representatives of the University
were unwelcome at the meeting
in question.We feel that we have
done all that is possible in order
to keep communication between
Charles Village residents and
Hopkins Open.
The views of the New-Letter as
voiced in its editorial
"Baltimorean" were well taken
and include many that we would

have voiced to the community
association. In the future,
perhaps Hopkins students will be
permitted to express them in
person.

J. D.for doodley squat- you can't complain
By LEO GORCEY
The Garrett Room
Milton S. Eisenhower Library
Open Wednesdays from 12 to 1 p.m.
Limited Menus
Live floor show
No credit cards accepted
Reservations not necessary
It was with great trepidation that I
went to the Garrett Room last
Wednesday to hear that legendary arbiter
of haute cuisine, that gourmand of the
gutter press, John Dorsey—I shudder to
pronounce the awful name. As all
readers of the Sun magazine well know,
John Dorsey is to Baltimore restaurants
what the boll weevil is to cotton plants.
When either one decides to feed his face,
you're gonna know about it, Jack.
Meeting great personalities is usually a
disappointment. They never live up to
your expectations and pre-conceptions. I
had figured the Great Culinary
Iconoclast J.D. for a fire-breathing,
gargantuan entity, perhaps a member of
Stan Lee's clan. I can't describe Dorsey's
appearance for you; all spectators were
cautioned not to photograph him or
describe him in print so as not to blow
his cover for the restaurant owners. The
only way to get away with being John
Dorsey is for no one to know what you
look like. Say, for example, you're
Polack Johnny down on Baltimore
Street. The Sunpaper's ace critic has just
walked into your Stygian hole of a food
emporium and you recognize him.
You're not going to treat him like an
ordinary customer. You're gonna lay
extra onions and garlic on his Coney
Island—on the house! He'll give you a
good review, your business will take off,
and you'll be drinking Dom Perignon
instead of National Boh. That just ain't
fair, to use the word Dorsey told us

doesn't belong in a critic's vocabulary. In
order for him to do his job right, Dorsey
has to be anonymous. Which is just as
well, for Dorsey has, as one judges from
his talk here, a passion for anonymity.
I'd really love to describe him in print:
A) because he might get mad, stamp his
foot, and splinter like Rumpelstiltskin,
which would be qpite amusing B)
because I was enjoined'not to, and I love
to break rules (vide my Hunter
Thompson fiasco) C) because, dammit,

some of my best friends are restaurant
owners and they deserve to know what
John Dorsey looks like so they can
refuse to serve him when he walks into
their places—it might lead to an
interesting court case.
Suffice it to say that Dorsey falls
somewhere in between Caspar
Milquetoast and Genghis Khan, by way
of Gilman School and Hahvid College.
I really should try to summarize Mr.
Dorsey's lecture on the job of a
reviewer—it was really heavy!—but I
can't remember all his learned references
to Edmund Wilson and Matthew Arnold.
I mean most of the capacity crowd there
in the Garrett Room was interested in
FOOD, can you dig it? I, for one,
wanted to know where the hell you can
get a decent crab cake or a good-sized
dry Manhattan without being taken to
the cleaners—and instead, Dorsey holds
forth on Criticism in Theory and
Practice from Plato to Gertrude Stein in
Forty Minutes. There's no way I can
summarize an erudite disquisition—such
as Mr. Dorsey—gave in this rag. It just

wouldn't be apropos. Besides, I didn't
take notes since I was too busy drinking
the University's free coffee, eating my
brown—bag special, and smoking a
Brazilian cigar left over from the Lincoln
Gordon military coup back in '64.
Anyway, Dorsey eventually gave the
folks what they wanted in the q-and-a
session after his lecture. He related an
amusing anecdote about a Glen Burnie
hashhouse with a big sign out front
saying: "John Dorsey ate here; But don't
let it stop you." Someone in the
audience reminded the "restaurant
reviewer malgre lui" of another local
beanery which boastfully advertises in
the Sun: 'We're not recommended by
John Dorsey, Deo Gratias." Ah, the
slings and arrows...all in the job of a
reviewer.
But, seriously folks, Baltimore owes
John Dorsey a huge debt of gratitude.
Since he started his weekly column in
1971, Baltimoreans have become
increasingly conscious of the quality of
food. Despite his pessimistic belief that
the masses know nothing about taste,

one can only conclude that they are
starting to learn. Go anywhere in
Baltimore and you will hear people
discussing Dorsey's latest review. The
man is both Sage and Celebrity, whether
he likes it or not. The pen, after all, is
mightier than the skillet.
And now for the review. The Garrett
Room suffers from its limited menu (le
cafe noir, seulement le cafe noir,
monsieur), but it still possesses a
delightful ambience. The decor is
conservative but elegant. Dr. Milton
Eisenhower's portrait lends a certain
pressence, a je ne sais quoi, to the room.
The Persian rug, which has seen better
days, yet exudes an exotic essence
(mayhap the half of baloney sandwich
the geek sitting in from of me dropped
midway through Matthew Arnold). The
coffee, finally, lacked character. Still
could not complain. As Kurt Vonnegut
might put it, this was the tab for lunch
Wednesday noon in the Garrett Room:
doodley squat.
Next week: Harley's.

David Porter

Writers Council promotes the pursuit of poetry
By MATT LASKOWSKI
As Hunter Thompson recently states,
Writing is miserable work." Attempting
to get one's writing published, however,
usually proves more miserable. Small
magazines of poetry and prose are the
unknown writer's only dependable
outlet.
Literary magazines funded by
universities are relatively few in number,
and are usually distributed without
charge to a limited group. External, "real
World," publications are more widely
distributed, always cost money, and
Often have the same flaws as the
I nstitutional publications. There are,
however, more of them. And you don't
have to attend any college to have a
Chance of gaining acceptance. For most,
these small independent magazines
afford the young writer a chance to
enter the elite world of the published.
The Maryland Writers Council is one
dominant local factor in this struggle.
.1 first became aware of the council's
existence while attending Poetry Project
last year. At the time, Poetry Project was
meeting Friday nights in the basement of
Theater Project, which as the publicity
on campus has told you, is located on
West Preston Street, near the heart of
downtown Baltimore. Poetry project is
S ponsored by the Maryland Writers
Council(MWC).
This past year was apparently a very
formative one for the Council, because
they now have their own building at 16
West Franklin Street, just a few doors
down from Tio Pepes, in the heart of
Baltimore City. The building, a gift from
a neighboring church, is a decrepit
rowhouse that is in the process of being
refurbished. It houses a printshop (the
Print Co-op), "a small Magazine little
Press emporium" (the Book Stall), and
Poetry Project.
Poetry Project deserves particular
recognition, since it is aimed at
stimulating public participation. Every
Friday night there are scheduled readings
by local poets. And as the posters say,
Open readings follow. Open readings
deserve some explanation. They are
circular functions, complete with
Prolonged reflective silences and a lot of
nodding. For some unexplained reason,
no comments are made, no discussions
ensue. There is never any pressure to
read, but I always come equipped with a
ream of my own poetry. You just don't
get a captive audience that often. The
Open readings are the dessert after a
sumptuous two-hour dinner of formal
Poetry readings.
I have implied that Poetry Project
exists primarily for poets. It does. It also
exists for everyone. No one who is
interested enough to come will feel

uncomfortable. Each week, the posters
are plastered all over campus, even on
Hugh Kenner's door, and 16 West
Franklin St. is only thirty cents away.
Poetry Project is just one facet of the
MWC programs. There are also writing
workshops, downtown, in Towson and
even in Charles Village. So, if you desire
the comments and discussion, an
instructor who actually writes, and some
literary stimulation outside of Hopkins'
limitations, investigate it. The courses
are eight weeks long and cover
journalism, poetry, fiction and criticism.
They began this week and cost a paltry
fifteen dollars. For information about
enrollment, call 332-1188 or drop in at
16 West Franklin.
While you're there you won't be able
to ignore the Book Stall. You'll find
more funny little poetry magazines by
people you've never heard of that you
ever thought possible. It's difficult to
browse because it's all so unfamiliar.
There is good poetry there and I
challenge you not to be intrigued.
The News Print Co-op, now in its first
full year of operation, exists solely to

make the writer's entrance into the
published world easier. Small editions
are published almost "at cost" and are
promoted and distributed as actively as
possible. A nationwide chain of such
co-ops is presently being coordinated
and each will attempt to carry
representative collections of the other's
stock. In other words, your poetry could
find its way onto a shelf in Duluth. This
is being created as an alternative to the
anapproachable commercial publishing
houses. The Maryland Writing Council is
empathatic about avoiding all of the
commercial run-around. They are
devoted to the writer, for they are
writers themselves.
The MWC also sponsors City Lit radio,
which is broadcast the first Sunday of
each month on WMJC-FM (91.5). Poetry
readings and radio drama in your very
own living room,in all the glory that FM
stereo can provide.
The News Print Co-op newsletter,
which is printed monthly, contains a
detailed schedule of happenings at
Theater Project and in the
neighborhood. Also some odd and

outspoken journalism. The Council also
publishes The Supplement to the
Bulletin of the Maryland Writers
Council—a bimonthly which deals
primarily with publishing news and
views. An interesting section called Hot
Flashes will keep you abreast of
upcoming local events.
Naturally all of this costs money, and
money is lacking. In order to negotiate a
successful business venture, they are
going to need some support from the
community. In this case, it isn't
exclusively monetary, but five dollars
will entitle you to a yearly membership
with a subscription to The Supolement,
a discount on any workshops you might
choose to take, and a complete lack of
guilt when you walk past the donation
can. If you can donate time, that will do
as well—and they'll pay you $2.75 an
hour.
If you write at all, then you should
feel the responsibility to drop in and talk
to some people there. If you like to
listen, then come by on Friday night.
And if you want to get published,
remember—it's a miserable business.

"Flesh Gordon"- a study in escapism
By MIKE DEAK
Much as I hate to admit if, "Flesh Gordon"is indeed a good movie. Perhaps this
lapse in my critical judgement can be
explained by a schematic recounting of
my previous encounters with the flick.
Our first encounter, came during my
rancid prep school days when, one cold
Connecticut night, I was sitting in Otley
Chesterfield's room leafing through
several "Playboy's and came upon a six
page pictorial "spread" on "Flesh
Gordon." Like a pervert squeezing a
nymphet's tit, the article siezed my
imagination and a night of rambuctious
dreams ensued.
About Ph yews later, shortly before
graduation, we managed to get a print of
"Flesh Gordon" for the annual senior
class "Blow-Out." I went with my
Liebste of the moment, Mary Lou
Hooper, and I remember what I saw of
the movie was just great. All, what fond
memories it brings back!
Just last Friday I happened into a
Burger King in Essex for dinner and
amazingly enough, the management was
showing movies, one of which was the
first chapter from a "Flash Gordon"
serial. Needless to say, this brought back
pleasurable, painful nostalgic memories.
As soon as I got back to my bachelor
apartment, I threw off my dinner jacket
and headed straight for the palatial Blue

Jay Cafe to get soaked.
On assignment this Monday, I hiked
down to the Charles Theatre to see
"Flesh Gordon" for the first time
seriously. As hard as I tried, I found it
impossible to find fault with this perfect
combination of two repulsive genres,
porno and science fiction movies. I don't
think I've enjoyed a movie more since I
saw "The Horn Blows at Midnight" last
Christmas.
A sex ray from outer space is driving
earth people mad with horniness. Orgies
erupt spontaneously on the streets. At a
convention in Tibet, Flesh Gordon has
discovered the origin of the ray (the
planet Porno) and tries to race home,
but his plane is hit by the dastardly sex
ray, and the pilots leave their controls to
join the fun in first class. Somehow,
Flesh is not affected and manages to
parachute with a busty stewardess, Dale
Ardour, seconds before the plane
crashes. They land in the hide-out of the
eccentric genius Dr. Jerkoff who
coincidentally has just built, from parts
ordered from Sears Roebuck, a phallic
spaceship. As Dale Ardour says, "The
likeness is remarkable."
Since Porno is at its closest point to
earth, Dr. Jerkoff's spaceship takes only
six minutes to get there. But the ship is
slowed by the passage through the
moronosphere and twisted wildly by the

sex ray, and has to make a crash landing
on Porno. There, our hero is met by
fierce penisoriuses and then taken
captive by Emperor Wang, the Perverted.
Wang, sitting high above his copulating
court, keeps Dr. Jerkoff for his own
laboratories, wants to marry Dale, and
throws Flesh to barbaric women. It
would be tasteless to reveal the rest of
the plot except to say to keep an eye on
the "power pasties."
In its own unique way, "Flesh
Gordon" is much better than Kubrick's
"2001." I actually believe the special
effects are more imaginative than
Kubrick's. But most importantly, "Flesh
Gordon" doesn't pretend, like the
shallow "2001," to be profound. As the
producers warn us at the beginning,
"Flesh Gordon" combines the spirit of
the old with the outrageousness of the
new. It fills a need for escapist
entertainment in these troubled times."
"Flesh Gordon" is playing this
weekend at Shriver Hall. I can't think of
a better film to see in older to escape
f;om the boredom of reality.
Admittedly, it is a sexist movie, but it
doesn't seem to matter; to take "Flesh
Gordon" seriously is a cardinal mistake.
Never Again
Go and enjoy "Flesh Gordon." Take
your Liebste, you will never see anything
like it again.

Nursing school graduates first 32
By LAINY STEPHANS
When the class of 1976 graduates next
spring, the first class of Hopkins' nursing
baccalaureate program will join the
procession beneath the Commencement
tent.
The nursing school, which opened this
year with 32 students, represents a new
trend in nursing and a departure from
the three-year registered nurse schools
which flourished a decade ago.
"For years alumni have seen the need
for a national movement for improving
nurse's training, to give them a greater
academic preparation and university
background," said a staff member at the
School of Health Services awhich
operates the school.
Doctors and hospital administrators
encouraged hospital diploma programs
and change over to a B.S. program in
nursing.

President Muller
ALUMNI, from page 4
The "education-vacation" offered by the
Association called the Alumni College
was held for the first time this summer
and drew rave reviews from the
participants. Almost 80 alumni and their
families spent a week at a college campus
in Southern Maryland studying Colonial
Maryland while enjoying the recreational
facilites—swimming, boating, tennis—at
St. Mary's College.
However, more than ever; the Alumni
is turning its attention to current
students and their needs.
The Alumni - Association has always,
worked in the past in helping recruit
students for Hopkins, usually through a
phone call to candidates. In addition, the
Association has contributed thousands

The Hopkins' school has accepted 28
female and four male students for the
two year program, which gives students a
junior and senior year course load of
nurse's training.
Laura Billman, who spent her first
two years at Notre Dame College, said
she is one of the few nursing students at
the school who entered with a
pre-nursing background. She said many
of the students majored in German,
Humanities, and Social Sciences during
their first two years of college.
School administrators were pleased
with the diversity in majors. "We
consider these varied backgrounds a
definite asset," said one faculty member.
"These people will be more aware of the
social and ecomomic effects of society
on their patients."
Billman said the graduates from this
program will be eligible for

administrative positions in hospitals,
careers in public health and work in
psychiatric institutions as well as
specialized nursing.
One staff member said that the
faculty is encouraging students to obtain
advanced degrees in the health field.
They are presenting a course of study
which enables students to eventually
become nurse practitioners. These nurses
often work on their own, performing
physicals, making prognoses and
following a patient's health for an
extended period of time.
Billman said the nursing students are
taking courses in anatomy and
physiology, physical growth and
development, nursing research and
psychology for their first semester. She
said students also work at the hospital
two days a week to gain practical
experience different areas.

october 17, 1975/news-letter/page 7

By DAVID GORBY
This Saturday, the Hopkins football
team will travel to Salisbury State in an
attempt to pick up their second
consecutive win of the year.

After last weekend's 8-7 victory over
Ursinus, the Blue Jays' record stands at
1-1-1. The Sea Gulls are 3-2 overall after
having destroyed Jersey City State last
Saturday 65-6 on the Gulls home field.

Backstroke to glory
By STEPHEN LEVIN
Wednesday marked an historic day in
the annals of Hopkins' athletics as
freshman swimmer Maria Mock departed
Baltimore for Mexico City to become
the first member of the Homewood
community ever to participate in the
prestigious Pan American Games.
Organized similarly to the Olympic
Games, the Pan-Am games are limited to
amateur athletes from the Americas and
Are held every four years in various
locations on either continent.
Maria will be representing her native
Puerto Rico in the 200-yard backstroke
and possibly some relays.
She started swimming competitively
at age 10 at a doctor's urging, hoping it
would improve her asthma. Since then,
her improvement has been rapid. By age
13, Maria was the best butterflier in
Puerto Rico, a title she still holds.
This will be her second appearance in
the Pan-Ams. In 1971, she travelled to
Cali, Colombia with the Puerto Rican
National Team and gained valuable
-experience as well as a fifth place finish
in the 200 fly.
Her decision to join her
brother— Carlos, a junior—here at
Homewood was predicated as much on
her desire to experience all four seasons
of the year, as on the quality and

intimate size of the University. "I was
going to. attend either Hopkins or
Florida State," the pert social and
behavioral sciences major explained.
"Both are fine swimming schools but the
size and the location of Hopkins as well
as the fine facilities (for swimming) and
the educational quality of the school led
me to select it.
"Also the fact that I'd never seen
snow,"she added "was important. Even
the leaves turning colors is new to me."
Frank Comfort, head swimming coach
at Hopkins noted the differences
between the qualifying standards
needed, pointing out that times are
faster here than in Puerto Rico "but
regardless of that, Maria will be a very,
very good U.S. swimmer."
Her late departure will put Maria at a
disadvantage being that she will arrive in
Mexico City only five days before her
event. Most other athletes have been
training in the high altitude for nearly a
month, acclimating themselves to the
unique conditions under which they will
be competing.
Maria will join another member of
Homewood's "extended" aquatic
community at the games. Wendy
Weinberg, a Baltimore high school senior
who trains under Coach Comfort at
Hopkins, will also be in Mexico City.

The hosts will provide the Jays with
some mighty stiff competition.
For Salisbury State this fall represents
only their third year of varsity gridiron
competition. In the 'past two years, the
Gulls have earned the reputation of
being a strong running team. In 1973
when they went 7-2 for the season,
Salisbury occupied the top slot in the
NAIA rushing charts.
Last year, in spite of a mediocre 4-4-1
record, the Gulls were 12th on the
NCAA Division III rushing charts.
Despite an attempt to broaden their
aerial attack this fall, Salisbury State has
remained primarily a rushing team. That
powerful ground attack provides the
basis for their offense.
The Sea Gulls are led offensively by
junior backs Levi Shade and Jim Watson,
both three-year starters. Last year
Watson ranked seventh in NCAA
Division III rushing with an average of
125.7 yards per game.
In the passing department, the hosts
are not quite as strong, though they do
have a fine quarterback in Dave Cooper
and good, speedy receivers in flanker
Tom Monthely and split end Jeff Polk.
Polk is an All-American trackman in the
100 and 200-yard dashes.
And, according to Head Coach Dick
Yobst, this year's Gull offensive line is
one of their best ever.
Defensively the Sea Gulls are strongest
in their secondary where they return
three of four starters, and on the
defensive line, with linebackers seeming
to be their weak link.
Salisbury State has a big team but
unlike Ursinus, they are mobile as well as
big, as opposed to the ponderous Bears.

David Porter

Hopkins will try to gull Salisbury

Second Quarter Action
Their strong ground game will severely
test the Hopkins rushing defense, a
group that has been inconsistent this
season but on an upward trend. After
allowing over 400 yards in the opener
against Muhlenberg, the Jays held
Ursinus to a paltry 112 yards on the
ground.
Great improvement has been shown
by star defensive tackle Willie Oliver,
who ahs done a yeoman job in the
middle of the Hopkins defensive corps.
Oliver, a 6'2", 210 pound junior from
Baltimore combines great strength which
allows him to stop the run, with
excellent quickness and mobility which
makes life hazardous for any opposing
signla-caller attempting to pass.
Joining Oliver in the pits will be Scott
Smith. "Stega" is a converted tight end
who has stepped in and done an
admirable job filling the injury-vacated
defensive tackle post.

J. D.for doodley squat- you can't complain
By LEO GORCEY
The Garrett Room
Milton S. Eisenhower Library
Open Wednesdays from 12 to 1 p.m.
Limited Menus
Live floor show
No credit cards accepted
Reservations not necessary
It was with great trepidation that I
went to the Garrett Room last
Wednesday to hear that legendary arbiter
of haute cuisine, that gourmand of the
gutter press, John Dorsey—I shudder to
pronounce the awful name. As all
readers of the Sun magazine well know,
John Dorsey is to Baltimore restaurants
what the boll weevil is to cotton plants.
When either one decides to feed his face,
you're gonna know about it, Jack.
Meeting great personalities is usually a
disappointment. They never live up to
your expectations and pre-conceptions. I
had figured the Great Culinary
Iconoclast J.D. for a fire-breathing,
gargantuan entity, perhaps a member of
Stan Lee's clan. I can't describe Dorsey's
appearance for you; all spectators were
cautioned not to photograph him or
describe him in print so as not to blow
his cover for the restaurant owners. The
only way to get away with being John
Dorsey is for no one to know what you
look like. Say, for example, you're
Polack Johnny down on Baltimore
Street. The Sunpaper's ace critic has just
walked into your Stygian hole of a food
emporium and you recognize him.
You're not going to treat him like an
ordinary customer. You're gonna lay
extra onions and garlic on his Coney
Island—on the house! He'll give you a
good review, your business will take off,
and you'll be drinking Dom Perignon
instead of National Boh. That just ain't
fair, to use the word Dorsey told us

doesn't belong in a critic's vocabulary. In
order for him to do his job right, Dorsey
has to be anonymous. Which is just as
well, for Dorsey has, as one judges from
his talk here, a passion for anonymity.
I'd really love to describe him in print:
A) because he might get mad, stamp his
foot, and splinter like Rumpelstiltskin,
which would be qpite amusing B)
because I was enjoined'not to, and I love
to break rules (vide my Hunter
Thompson fiasco) C) because, dammit,

some of my best friends are restaurant
owners and they deserve to know what
John Dorsey looks like so they can
refuse to serve him when he walks into
their places—it might lead to an
interesting court case.
Suffice it to say that Dorsey falls
somewhere in between Caspar
Milquetoast and Genghis Khan, by way
of Gilman School and Hahvid College.
I really should try to summarize Mr.
Dorsey's lecture on the job of a
reviewer—it was really heavy!—but I
can't remember all his learned references
to Edmund Wilson and Matthew Arnold.
I mean most of the capacity crowd there
in the Garrett Room was interested in
FOOD, can you dig it? I, for one,
wanted to know where the hell you can
get a decent crab cake or a good-sized
dry Manhattan without being taken to
the cleaners—and instead, Dorsey holds
forth on Criticism in Theory and
Practice from Plato to Gertrude Stein in
Forty Minutes. There's no way I can
summarize an erudite disquisition—such
as Mr. Dorsey—gave in this rag. It just

wouldn't be apropos. Besides, I didn't
take notes since I was too busy drinking
the University's free coffee, eating my
brown—bag special, and smoking a
Brazilian cigar left over from the Lincoln
Gordon military coup back in '64.
Anyway, Dorsey eventually gave the
folks what they wanted in the q-and-a
session after his lecture. He related an
amusing anecdote about a Glen Burnie
hashhouse with a big sign out front
saying: "John Dorsey ate here; But don't
let it stop you." Someone in the
audience reminded the "restaurant
reviewer malgre lui" of another local
beanery which boastfully advertises in
the Sun: 'We're not recommended by
John Dorsey, Deo Gratias." Ah, the
slings and arrows...all in the job of a
reviewer.
But, seriously folks, Baltimore owes
John Dorsey a huge debt of gratitude.
Since he started his weekly column in
1971, Baltimoreans have become
increasingly conscious of the quality of
food. Despite his pessimistic belief that
the masses know nothing about taste,

one can only conclude that they are
starting to learn. Go anywhere in
Baltimore and you will hear people
discussing Dorsey's latest review. The
man is both Sage and Celebrity, whether
he likes it or not. The pen, after all, is
mightier than the skillet.
And now for the review. The Garrett
Room suffers from its limited menu (le
cafe noir, seulement le cafe noir,
monsieur), but it still possesses a
delightful ambience. The decor is
conservative but elegant. Dr. Milton
Eisenhower's portrait lends a certain
pressence, a je ne sais quoi, to the room.
The Persian rug, which has seen better
days, yet exudes an exotic essence
(mayhap the half of baloney sandwich
the geek sitting in from of me dropped
midway through Matthew Arnold). The
coffee, finally, lacked character. Still
could not complain. As Kurt Vonnegut
might put it, this was the tab for lunch
Wednesday noon in the Garrett Room:
doodley squat.
Next week: Harley's.

David Porter

Writers Council promotes the pursuit of poetry
By MATT LASKOWSKI
As Hunter Thompson recently states,
Writing is miserable work." Attempting
to get one's writing published, however,
usually proves more miserable. Small
magazines of poetry and prose are the
unknown writer's only dependable
outlet.
Literary magazines funded by
universities are relatively few in number,
and are usually distributed without
charge to a limited group. External, "real
World," publications are more widely
distributed, always cost money, and
Often have the same flaws as the
I nstitutional publications. There are,
however, more of them. And you don't
have to attend any college to have a
Chance of gaining acceptance. For most,
these small independent magazines
afford the young writer a chance to
enter the elite world of the published.
The Maryland Writers Council is one
dominant local factor in this struggle.
.1 first became aware of the council's
existence while attending Poetry Project
last year. At the time, Poetry Project was
meeting Friday nights in the basement of
Theater Project, which as the publicity
on campus has told you, is located on
West Preston Street, near the heart of
downtown Baltimore. Poetry project is
S ponsored by the Maryland Writers
Council(MWC).
This past year was apparently a very
formative one for the Council, because
they now have their own building at 16
West Franklin Street, just a few doors
down from Tio Pepes, in the heart of
Baltimore City. The building, a gift from
a neighboring church, is a decrepit
rowhouse that is in the process of being
refurbished. It houses a printshop (the
Print Co-op), "a small Magazine little
Press emporium" (the Book Stall), and
Poetry Project.
Poetry Project deserves particular
recognition, since it is aimed at
stimulating public participation. Every
Friday night there are scheduled readings
by local poets. And as the posters say,
Open readings follow. Open readings
deserve some explanation. They are
circular functions, complete with
Prolonged reflective silences and a lot of
nodding. For some unexplained reason,
no comments are made, no discussions
ensue. There is never any pressure to
read, but I always come equipped with a
ream of my own poetry. You just don't
get a captive audience that often. The
Open readings are the dessert after a
sumptuous two-hour dinner of formal
Poetry readings.
I have implied that Poetry Project
exists primarily for poets. It does. It also
exists for everyone. No one who is
interested enough to come will feel

uncomfortable. Each week, the posters
are plastered all over campus, even on
Hugh Kenner's door, and 16 West
Franklin St. is only thirty cents away.
Poetry Project is just one facet of the
MWC programs. There are also writing
workshops, downtown, in Towson and
even in Charles Village. So, if you desire
the comments and discussion, an
instructor who actually writes, and some
literary stimulation outside of Hopkins'
limitations, investigate it. The courses
are eight weeks long and cover
journalism, poetry, fiction and criticism.
They began this week and cost a paltry
fifteen dollars. For information about
enrollment, call 332-1188 or drop in at
16 West Franklin.
While you're there you won't be able
to ignore the Book Stall. You'll find
more funny little poetry magazines by
people you've never heard of that you
ever thought possible. It's difficult to
browse because it's all so unfamiliar.
There is good poetry there and I
challenge you not to be intrigued.
The News Print Co-op, now in its first
full year of operation, exists solely to

make the writer's entrance into the
published world easier. Small editions
are published almost "at cost" and are
promoted and distributed as actively as
possible. A nationwide chain of such
co-ops is presently being coordinated
and each will attempt to carry
representative collections of the other's
stock. In other words, your poetry could
find its way onto a shelf in Duluth. This
is being created as an alternative to the
anapproachable commercial publishing
houses. The Maryland Writing Council is
empathatic about avoiding all of the
commercial run-around. They are
devoted to the writer, for they are
writers themselves.
The MWC also sponsors City Lit radio,
which is broadcast the first Sunday of
each month on WMJC-FM (91.5). Poetry
readings and radio drama in your very
own living room,in all the glory that FM
stereo can provide.
The News Print Co-op newsletter,
which is printed monthly, contains a
detailed schedule of happenings at
Theater Project and in the
neighborhood. Also some odd and

outspoken journalism. The Council also
publishes The Supplement to the
Bulletin of the Maryland Writers
Council—a bimonthly which deals
primarily with publishing news and
views. An interesting section called Hot
Flashes will keep you abreast of
upcoming local events.
Naturally all of this costs money, and
money is lacking. In order to negotiate a
successful business venture, they are
going to need some support from the
community. In this case, it isn't
exclusively monetary, but five dollars
will entitle you to a yearly membership
with a subscription to The Supolement,
a discount on any workshops you might
choose to take, and a complete lack of
guilt when you walk past the donation
can. If you can donate time, that will do
as well—and they'll pay you $2.75 an
hour.
If you write at all, then you should
feel the responsibility to drop in and talk
to some people there. If you like to
listen, then come by on Friday night.
And if you want to get published,
remember—it's a miserable business.

"Flesh Gordon"- a study in escapism
By MIKE DEAK
Much as I hate to admit if, "Flesh Gordon"is indeed a good movie. Perhaps this
lapse in my critical judgement can be
explained by a schematic recounting of
my previous encounters with the flick.
Our first encounter, came during my
rancid prep school days when, one cold
Connecticut night, I was sitting in Otley
Chesterfield's room leafing through
several "Playboy's and came upon a six
page pictorial "spread" on "Flesh
Gordon." Like a pervert squeezing a
nymphet's tit, the article siezed my
imagination and a night of rambuctious
dreams ensued.
About Ph yews later, shortly before
graduation, we managed to get a print of
"Flesh Gordon" for the annual senior
class "Blow-Out." I went with my
Liebste of the moment, Mary Lou
Hooper, and I remember what I saw of
the movie was just great. All, what fond
memories it brings back!
Just last Friday I happened into a
Burger King in Essex for dinner and
amazingly enough, the management was
showing movies, one of which was the
first chapter from a "Flash Gordon"
serial. Needless to say, this brought back
pleasurable, painful nostalgic memories.
As soon as I got back to my bachelor
apartment, I threw off my dinner jacket
and headed straight for the palatial Blue

Jay Cafe to get soaked.
On assignment this Monday, I hiked
down to the Charles Theatre to see
"Flesh Gordon" for the first time
seriously. As hard as I tried, I found it
impossible to find fault with this perfect
combination of two repulsive genres,
porno and science fiction movies. I don't
think I've enjoyed a movie more since I
saw "The Horn Blows at Midnight" last
Christmas.
A sex ray from outer space is driving
earth people mad with horniness. Orgies
erupt spontaneously on the streets. At a
convention in Tibet, Flesh Gordon has
discovered the origin of the ray (the
planet Porno) and tries to race home,
but his plane is hit by the dastardly sex
ray, and the pilots leave their controls to
join the fun in first class. Somehow,
Flesh is not affected and manages to
parachute with a busty stewardess, Dale
Ardour, seconds before the plane
crashes. They land in the hide-out of the
eccentric genius Dr. Jerkoff who
coincidentally has just built, from parts
ordered from Sears Roebuck, a phallic
spaceship. As Dale Ardour says, "The
likeness is remarkable."
Since Porno is at its closest point to
earth, Dr. Jerkoff's spaceship takes only
six minutes to get there. But the ship is
slowed by the passage through the
moronosphere and twisted wildly by the

sex ray, and has to make a crash landing
on Porno. There, our hero is met by
fierce penisoriuses and then taken
captive by Emperor Wang, the Perverted.
Wang, sitting high above his copulating
court, keeps Dr. Jerkoff for his own
laboratories, wants to marry Dale, and
throws Flesh to barbaric women. It
would be tasteless to reveal the rest of
the plot except to say to keep an eye on
the "power pasties."
In its own unique way, "Flesh
Gordon" is much better than Kubrick's
"2001." I actually believe the special
effects are more imaginative than
Kubrick's. But most importantly, "Flesh
Gordon" doesn't pretend, like the
shallow "2001," to be profound. As the
producers warn us at the beginning,
"Flesh Gordon" combines the spirit of
the old with the outrageousness of the
new. It fills a need for escapist
entertainment in these troubled times."
"Flesh Gordon" is playing this
weekend at Shriver Hall. I can't think of
a better film to see in older to escape
f;om the boredom of reality.
Admittedly, it is a sexist movie, but it
doesn't seem to matter; to take "Flesh
Gordon" seriously is a cardinal mistake.
Never Again
Go and enjoy "Flesh Gordon." Take
your Liebste, you will never see anything
like it again.

Nursing school graduates first 32
By LAINY STEPHANS
When the class of 1976 graduates next
spring, the first class of Hopkins' nursing
baccalaureate program will join the
procession beneath the Commencement
tent.
The nursing school, which opened this
year with 32 students, represents a new
trend in nursing and a departure from
the three-year registered nurse schools
which flourished a decade ago.
"For years alumni have seen the need
for a national movement for improving
nurse's training, to give them a greater
academic preparation and university
background," said a staff member at the
School of Health Services awhich
operates the school.
Doctors and hospital administrators
encouraged hospital diploma programs
and change over to a B.S. program in
nursing.

President Muller
ALUMNI, from page 4
The "education-vacation" offered by the
Association called the Alumni College
was held for the first time this summer
and drew rave reviews from the
participants. Almost 80 alumni and their
families spent a week at a college campus
in Southern Maryland studying Colonial
Maryland while enjoying the recreational
facilites—swimming, boating, tennis—at
St. Mary's College.
However, more than ever; the Alumni
is turning its attention to current
students and their needs.
The Alumni - Association has always,
worked in the past in helping recruit
students for Hopkins, usually through a
phone call to candidates. In addition, the
Association has contributed thousands

The Hopkins' school has accepted 28
female and four male students for the
two year program, which gives students a
junior and senior year course load of
nurse's training.
Laura Billman, who spent her first
two years at Notre Dame College, said
she is one of the few nursing students at
the school who entered with a
pre-nursing background. She said many
of the students majored in German,
Humanities, and Social Sciences during
their first two years of college.
School administrators were pleased
with the diversity in majors. "We
consider these varied backgrounds a
definite asset," said one faculty member.
"These people will be more aware of the
social and ecomomic effects of society
on their patients."
Billman said the graduates from this
program will be eligible for

administrative positions in hospitals,
careers in public health and work in
psychiatric institutions as well as
specialized nursing.
One staff member said that the
faculty is encouraging students to obtain
advanced degrees in the health field.
They are presenting a course of study
which enables students to eventually
become nurse practitioners. These nurses
often work on their own, performing
physicals, making prognoses and
following a patient's health for an
extended period of time.
Billman said the nursing students are
taking courses in anatomy and
physiology, physical growth and
development, nursing research and
psychology for their first semester. She
said students also work at the hospital
two days a week to gain practical
experience different areas.

october 17, 1975/news-letter/page 7

By DAVID GORBY
This Saturday, the Hopkins football
team will travel to Salisbury State in an
attempt to pick up their second
consecutive win of the year.

After last weekend's 8-7 victory over
Ursinus, the Blue Jays' record stands at
1-1-1. The Sea Gulls are 3-2 overall after
having destroyed Jersey City State last
Saturday 65-6 on the Gulls home field.

Backstroke to glory
By STEPHEN LEVIN
Wednesday marked an historic day in
the annals of Hopkins' athletics as
freshman swimmer Maria Mock departed
Baltimore for Mexico City to become
the first member of the Homewood
community ever to participate in the
prestigious Pan American Games.
Organized similarly to the Olympic
Games, the Pan-Am games are limited to
amateur athletes from the Americas and
Are held every four years in various
locations on either continent.
Maria will be representing her native
Puerto Rico in the 200-yard backstroke
and possibly some relays.
She started swimming competitively
at age 10 at a doctor's urging, hoping it
would improve her asthma. Since then,
her improvement has been rapid. By age
13, Maria was the best butterflier in
Puerto Rico, a title she still holds.
This will be her second appearance in
the Pan-Ams. In 1971, she travelled to
Cali, Colombia with the Puerto Rican
National Team and gained valuable
-experience as well as a fifth place finish
in the 200 fly.
Her decision to join her
brother— Carlos, a junior—here at
Homewood was predicated as much on
her desire to experience all four seasons
of the year, as on the quality and

intimate size of the University. "I was
going to. attend either Hopkins or
Florida State," the pert social and
behavioral sciences major explained.
"Both are fine swimming schools but the
size and the location of Hopkins as well
as the fine facilities (for swimming) and
the educational quality of the school led
me to select it.
"Also the fact that I'd never seen
snow,"she added "was important. Even
the leaves turning colors is new to me."
Frank Comfort, head swimming coach
at Hopkins noted the differences
between the qualifying standards
needed, pointing out that times are
faster here than in Puerto Rico "but
regardless of that, Maria will be a very,
very good U.S. swimmer."
Her late departure will put Maria at a
disadvantage being that she will arrive in
Mexico City only five days before her
event. Most other athletes have been
training in the high altitude for nearly a
month, acclimating themselves to the
unique conditions under which they will
be competing.
Maria will join another member of
Homewood's "extended" aquatic
community at the games. Wendy
Weinberg, a Baltimore high school senior
who trains under Coach Comfort at
Hopkins, will also be in Mexico City.

The hosts will provide the Jays with
some mighty stiff competition.
For Salisbury State this fall represents
only their third year of varsity gridiron
competition. In the 'past two years, the
Gulls have earned the reputation of
being a strong running team. In 1973
when they went 7-2 for the season,
Salisbury occupied the top slot in the
NAIA rushing charts.
Last year, in spite of a mediocre 4-4-1
record, the Gulls were 12th on the
NCAA Division III rushing charts.
Despite an attempt to broaden their
aerial attack this fall, Salisbury State has
remained primarily a rushing team. That
powerful ground attack provides the
basis for their offense.
The Sea Gulls are led offensively by
junior backs Levi Shade and Jim Watson,
both three-year starters. Last year
Watson ranked seventh in NCAA
Division III rushing with an average of
125.7 yards per game.
In the passing department, the hosts
are not quite as strong, though they do
have a fine quarterback in Dave Cooper
and good, speedy receivers in flanker
Tom Monthely and split end Jeff Polk.
Polk is an All-American trackman in the
100 and 200-yard dashes.
And, according to Head Coach Dick
Yobst, this year's Gull offensive line is
one of their best ever.
Defensively the Sea Gulls are strongest
in their secondary where they return
three of four starters, and on the
defensive line, with linebackers seeming
to be their weak link.
Salisbury State has a big team but
unlike Ursinus, they are mobile as well as
big, as opposed to the ponderous Bears.

David Porter

Hopkins will try to gull Salisbury

Second Quarter Action
Their strong ground game will severely
test the Hopkins rushing defense, a
group that has been inconsistent this
season but on an upward trend. After
allowing over 400 yards in the opener
against Muhlenberg, the Jays held
Ursinus to a paltry 112 yards on the
ground.
Great improvement has been shown
by star defensive tackle Willie Oliver,
who ahs done a yeoman job in the
middle of the Hopkins defensive corps.
Oliver, a 6'2", 210 pound junior from
Baltimore combines great strength which
allows him to stop the run, with
excellent quickness and mobility which
makes life hazardous for any opposing
signla-caller attempting to pass.
Joining Oliver in the pits will be Scott
Smith. "Stega" is a converted tight end
who has stepped in and done an
admirable job filling the injury-vacated
defensive tackle post.
